name: calva-backseat-driver
description: Make CoPilot an Interactive Programmer, tools for VS Code CoPilot. Can also be run as an MCP server

calva-backseat-driver.enableReplEvaluati.markdownDescription:
Enable the REPL evaluation tool.

 **⚠️ SECURITY WARNING**: _When enabled and you have also started the MCP server, any network client with access to the MCP server can execute arbitrary code in your REPL environment._ That said, CoPilot and other compliant MCP clients will default to a low-trust mode with confirmation before any evaluation.

calva-backseat-driver.autoStartMCPServer.markdownDescription: Automatically start the MCP server when the extension is activated.

languageModelTools.name: evaluate_clojure_code
languageModelTools.modelDescription: Evaluate code using Calva's REPL connection. Enables AI Interactive Programming. Use this to make sure your seggested edits work as you advertise, before suggesting them. The REPL holds the truth!
languageModelTools.userDescription: Evaluate Clojure or ClojureScript code in the connected REPL.

namespace.description: Fully qualified namespace in which to evaluate the code. E.g. if calling functions in a file you are reading, it is probably the namespace of that file that should be provided. If it is the first time you use a namespace, start with evaluating its ns-form in the `user` or `cljs.user` namespace (as appropriate).

replSessionKey.description: The Calva REPL session to evaluate the code via. It should be `clj` for the Clojure REPL, `cljs` for the ClojureScript REPL and `cljc` for the current session for `.cljc` files.

languageModelTools.name: get_symbol_info
languageModelTools.modelDescription: Get detailed information about a Clojure symbol from the connected REPL.
languageModelTools.userDescription: Look up documentation for a Clojure symbol.

clojureSymbol.description: The symbol to look up info for

namespace.description: Fully qualified namespace in which to evaluate the code. E.g. if calling functions in a file you are reading, it is probably the namespace of that file that should be provided.

replSessionKey.description: The Calva REPL session to evaluate the code in. For Clojure, ClojureScript, and Common, respectively. Often the same as the extension of the file you are working with. One of `clj`, `cljs`, or `cljc`.

languageModelTools.name: get_clojuredocs_info
languageModelTools.modelDescription: Look up information, examples, see also:s, and more about a Clojure Core symbol from clojuredocs.org.
languageModelTools.userDescription: Get examples and usage from clojuredocs.org

clojureSymbol.description: The symbol to look up on clojuredocs.org

languageModelTools.name: get_repl_output_log
languageModelTools.modelDescription: Get REPL output messages from  Calva output window. Returns REPL output since `since-line`. Start with since-line=0 and use the last line number from previous output for subsequent calls. This is your window into the running application. Invoke it often as files are edited and/or you evaluate code.

sinceLine.description: Output line-number after which you want output. Use `0` for your first request of output.

languageModelTools.name: balance_brackets
languageModelTools.modelDescription: Heal the structure of your Clojure code before suggesting it to the user. If you are editing a file, use this tool on the whole file as it would look after edits are applied, and you will seldom see the problem/error report complain about inbalanced brackets.

text.description: Clojure code that may need balancing of its brackets. (Often the whole would-be file.)

scripts.vscode:prepublish: npm run clean && npm run release
